user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of expire_sessions:
```c
static void
expire_sessions (void)
{
  struct Session *pos;
  struct Session *prev;
  struct Session *next;
  time_t now;

  now = time (NULL);
  prev = NULL;
  pos = sessions;
  while (NULL != pos)
  {
    next = pos->next;
    if (now - pos->start > 60 * 60)
    {
      /* expire sessions after 1h */
      if (NULL == prev)
        sessions = pos->next;
      else
        prev->next = next;
      free (pos);
    }
    else
      prev = pos;
    pos = next;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  struct Session *next;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated in this context. 'next' is later assigned to prev->next (type struct Session *), so it cannot be safely changed to 'const struct Session *' without changing other code or performing a cast. A violation would occur if 'next' were only used for read-only access to the session objects and never assigned to a non-const pointer; in that case it should be declared as 'const struct Session *next;'.
